results.headline: The Further Adventures of the Fedora and Whip
results.summary_short: There’s plenty of frantic energy in “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull,” lots of noise and money too, but what’s absent is any sense of rediscovery.
results.display_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull

results.headline: Tying Knots That Bind Lives Despite the Divisions of Generation and Nationality
results.summary_short: In the course of the extraordinary film “The Edge of Heaven,” children are lost, lost parents are never found, and generational and geographical distances grow wider.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Edge of Heaven

results.headline: Torn by the Contradictions of Being Gay and Muslim
results.summary_short: “A Jihad for Love” is a dispatch from the outer limits of marginalization: a documentary on devout Muslims struggling with their homosexuality.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bolivia: Making Waves

results.headline: Two Friends, Two Novels, One Mailbox: Lives at the Speed of Ambition
results.summary_short: An exuberant, exhilaratingly playful testament to being young and hungry, “Reprise” is a blast of unadulterated movie pleasure.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reprise

results.headline: Another Abraham’s Story, With a Different Ending
results.summary_short: “My Father My Lord” observes the severe family life of an ultra-Orthodox rabbi.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Father My Lord

results.headline: When Selling a Soul, Consider the Price
results.summary_short: Christian Petzold’s enigmatic thriller “Yella” offers a surreal X-ray vision of cutthroat capitalism in 21st-century Germany.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yella

results.headline: A Teenager’s Betrayal in Brooklyn
results.summary_short: Although “Sangre de Mi Sangre” exhibits a heartfelt connection with illegal immigrants, its myriad inconsistencies and strained plotting are frustrating.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sangre de mi sangre

results.headline: This Is Basketball, Boys; It’s Not Rocket Science
results.summary_short: “Quantum Hoops” tells the story of the California Institute of Technology’s men’s basketball team, a farcical topic in the context of college sports.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quantum Hoops

results.headline: Out of the Wardrobe, Into a War Zone
results.summary_short: “Prince Caspian” is quite a bit darker than “The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe,” both in look and in mood. It is also in some ways more satisfying.
results.display_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian

results.headline: In Paraguay, Time Melts in the Torpid Air
results.summary_short: That “Paraguayan Hammock” happens to be one of the few features to emerge from Paraguay in recent decades in no way diminishes its rarity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paraguayan Hammock

results.headline: A Family That Surfs to a Beat: Its Own
results.summary_short: “Surfwise” has a bohemian vibe and a cool sheen, but it’s an eager-to-please, pleasing commercial enterprise with a reassuring narrative arc.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Surfwise

results.headline: When Life Gives Lemons, Pick Up a Pool Stick
results.summary_short: “Turn the River” is a finely observed portrait of a desperate working-class woman who refuses to play by ordinary rules.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Turn the River

results.headline: After Them the Monsoon: Two Worlds Collide in India
results.summary_short: The ingredients of the Indian director Santosh Sivan’s period piece “Before the Rains” may be awfully familiar, but the film lends them the force of tragedy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before the Rains

results.headline: Youthful Energy and Religious Pain
results.summary_short: Adam Hootnick’s “Unsettled” makes the political personal, drawing a scattershot yet intimate picture of a nation divided.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unsettled

results.headline: Average Teenage Girl, Assembling a Life Without a Set of Instructions
results.summary_short: Viewed as the sum of its sad incidents, “The Tracey Fragments” seems like the kind of adolescent melodrama that has become a staple of young-adult literature.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Tracey Fragments

results.headline: Going for the Finger-Licking Gusto
results.summary_short: “Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead” is just about as perfect as a film predicated on the joys of projectile vomiting and explosive diarrhea can be.
results.display_title: Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead

results.headline: A Dashing Agent in Egypt
results.summary_short: The hero of “OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies” might be described as a French equivalent of James Bond.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies

results.headline: Aural Examination
results.summary_short: “Noise,” the second part of a projected “fanatic trilogy,” is shallow and loud.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Noise

results.headline: After Making It Out of Paris, Finding There’s No Escape
results.summary_short: The real surprise of “Frontier(s)” is that this creepy, bloody contemporary gross-out also has some ideas, visual and otherwise, wedged among its sanguineous drips.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frontier(s)

results.headline: Broken Spirits on the Mend
results.summary_short: Shot piecemeal over the course of four years on locations in 18 countries, “The Fall” is a genuine labor of love — and a real bore.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Fall
